typeData.textContent:
Welcome to the eighth week of the course!

Assigned Readings
You should carefully read the assigned readings for this part of the course (i.e., OpenStax Psychology text: Chapter 5 Introduction; Chapter 5, Sections 5.1 to 5.3) before proceeding on with this part of the course. You will have a chance to check your understanding of the readings.

It's important to note that not all of the material that is in the text is in the video lectures, and vice versa. So, it's important to keep up with both.

nodes.title: Receptive Fields - Drag the Words (Liane Tang)
nodes.description: Drag the words into the correct boxes :)

typeData.textContent:
What is a visual receptive field? 
A visual receptive field is located in the retina, and is responsible for firing action potentials whenever the corresponding stimulus with the correct set of properties enters the receptive field. Ganglion cells are part of a visual receptive field.

What are ganglion receptive fields? 
Ganglion receptive fields are part of the retina and of a center-surround structure, which means that light falling on the center of a receptive field produces the opposite effect in comparison to when the light falls on the peripheral of a receptive field (Ranpura & Fitzgerald, 2019)

What is the difference between an on-center ganglion cell and an off-center ganglion cell?
An on-center ganglion cell will increase in firing rate/ the number of action potentials produced when light is hitting the center of their receptive field. Off-center ganglion cells, on the other hand, will increase in firing rate when light is exposed to the peripheral of their receptive field. 

Ranpura, A., Fitzgerald, A., (2019, October 09). Overview of Receptive Fields. Retrieved from https://brainconnection.brainhq.com/2004/03/06/overview-of-receptive-fields/

nodes.title: Subliminal Messages in Marketing (Wesley Lam)

nodes.title: Path of a Neural Signal through the Visual System (Alex Barber-Cross)
nodes.description: Describes the path of a neural signal from a photoreceptor to the primary visual cortex with some concept check questions along the way. Connects to "Path of Light through the Visual System (Heather Cathcart)".

typeData.textContent:
The retina geniculate-striate system is a complex system that brings information taken from the eyes to be processed by the brain. Information taken from our eyes to our nasal retina (retina on the side of your nose) is brought to the lateral geniculate nucleus on the opposite hemisphere. After, it gets sent to the contralateral primary visual cortex for the brain to interpret the image. So for example, if something is triggered on the left vision field, the left nasal retina will send the signal to the right lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) which sends it to the right primary visual cortex. On the other hand, if the right visual field stimulates the temporal retina (retina on the side of your temples), it will send the signal to the ipsilateral LGN, to the primary visual cortex.. In other words, the signal would stay on one hemisphere of the brain. The retina geniculate-striate system has a pattern of cell networking; photoreceptors, bipolar cells, ganglion cells. This whole process can be extremely extensive, and learning how the different types of cells communicate is also tricky. A Marshall 1949 article shows that cats respond extremely well to both ipsilateral and contralateral stimuli. However, there is some evidence to show that it would be extremely different if asphyxia was a factor.

References
Marshall, W. H. (1949, January 3). EXCITABILITY CYCLE AND INTERACTION IN GENICULATE-STRIATE SYSTEM OF CAT*. Retrieved from https://journals.physiology.org/doi/pdf/10.1152/jn.1949.12.4.277

nodes.title: The Gambling industry and its reliance on visual stimulus

typeData.textContent:
Week 8â€™s reading involves the topic of signal detection theory and sensory adaptation. In reference to the textbook: signal detection theory refers to reacting to stimulus that is in contrast to current mental state and surroundings, and sensory adaptation refers to adapting to stimuli.

Both these ideas relate to each other in terms of explaining how humans react to changing or non changing stimuli. The gambling industry, mainly casinos, uses the idea of perception and changing stimuli to keep customers playing. 

Signal detection theory: 
Signal detection can be utilized primarily in slot machines. When one is playing a slot, players are often focused, hoping to catch matching lines of images. At this stage, slot machine displays are stoic, and quiet. Typically the only images moving are the moving lines of the game. This use of forcing the player to visually pay attention affects the attentiveness of their mental state, which is what the signal detection theory tackles. When a player wins a sum on a slot machine, casinoâ€™s often use flashing lights and sounds to notify that a player has won. Oftentimes, bright and colorful animations accompany the notification of a win. This contrast of slow and menial visuals into bright flashing lights and animation influences the player on the value of winning. Slot machines use the idea of visual stimulation intensity and its psychological influence. 

Sensory adaptation:
Sensory adaptation similarly plays into the idea of contrast. Compared to a home,  the ambiance of a casino with its flashing lights and sounds is naturally more stimulating. This over-stimulating environment is used to an advantage, as when a player returns home, the individual is forced to adapt to a less stimulating environment. This could make way for a sense of wanting to return to what they had adapted to, a high stimulating environment. 

Below is some info on casino and visual stimuli. 
University of British Columbia. "Casino lights and sounds encourage risky decision-making." ScienceDaily. ScienceDaily, 29 October 2018. <www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2018/10/181029130911.htm>.

nodes.title: Light and Sound Waves (Ricardo Liu)
nodes.description: see link

linkMetadata.title: Light and Sound Waves (Ricardo Liu) â€“ PSYC 101 2020 Summer: Tapestry
linkMetadata.description: Moreover, the amplitude of sound waves affects the loudness of the sounds that we perceive. Large amplitudes result in loud sounds, while small amplitudes result in quite sounds. The loudness of sounds is often measured as decibels (dB). Sounds that are harmful to our auditory system measure around 80 dB. Nonetheless, our perception of loudness is not only influenced by the amplitude of sound waves. The way amplitude and frequency interact with each other also plays an important role in determining the loudness of sounds. For instance, some sounds that are out of our audible range will be inaudible no matter how large the amplitude of the sound wave is.

nodes.title: The Evolution of Colour Vision (Michael Choi)
nodes.description: Extension of Colour Vision node on the "evolution of colour vision."

typeData.textContent:
Evolution has had a great impact on the mechanisms of colour perception. This is often correlated with the evolution of having to recognize proper food sources and survival. We can see the evidence based on the evolution of colour vision in herbivores, primates, and nocturnals specifically. Studying how light and colour create a unique perception of identifying food for all species helps to create a better understanding of how our eyes have developed in order to perceive colour for survival. 

The colour vision of herbivores have evolved around the essential need to find the proper leaves or flowers to feed on. For example, hummingbirds rely on their ability to identify the particular colours of flowers to know their targets. Most herbivores do not see colours in the trichromatic ways humans have evolved to perceive colour. Rather, many herbivores possess the dichromatic vision as they are able to distinguish the colourful plants apart from the green leaves. Unlike the herbivores, nocturnals have developed in a different fashion in term of eyesight and colour vision

Nocturnal animalsâ€™ eyesights have evolved with less-developed colour vision, however it attracts the adequate light necessary to function to find food during darker nights. This allows environments that may be pitch black to primates, be â€œdimâ€ lighting for nocturnal animals. Due to having to see in such dark conditions, nocturnals possess big eyes that contain many more rods that can help sense very dim, scattered lights that do not process a coloured images the same way having many cones in their eyes would. This contrasts the evolution of the trichromatic vision that most primates have evolved into using.

	In terms of primates such as monkeys, apes, and of course humans, we have evolved into diurnal (daytime) eye activity to help us identify foods such as fruits and leaves. The early primatesâ€™ transition into diurnal activities allowed the development of the highly advantageous trichromatic colour vision that allowed for identification of finding fruit (as the â€œfruit theoryâ€ stated in the past), and the adaptability to survive in daylight by perceiving accurate colour vision.

	In the end, the evidence shows that the evolution of colour vision has revolved around the idea of survival, which translates into the need to find food sources. As nocturnal bats differ from omnivorous humans, who differ from herbivorous deers, the necessary perception of light and colour has caused the eyes of different species to evolve in different formations and theoretical methods (eg. trichromatic theory) in order for survival.

Bibliography

https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-319-42096-7_8

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Color_vision#:~:text=Color%20vision%20is%20an%20ability,distributions)%20independently%20of%20light%20intensity.

https://northernwoodlands.org/outside_story/article/night-vision-how-animals-see

linkMetadata.title: W8: Color Vision (Karat Wannissorn) â€“ PSYC 101 2020 Summer: Tapestry
linkMetadata.description: An example of colour constancy is in the image of strawberries below. The strawberries are illuminated with blue light and are objectively grey. However, a lot of people see red, since our brain considers the context of the picture. (Strawberries are typically red, so they are constantly perceived as red.) This theory also proves that colour is a psychophysical property, not totally physical.

nodes.title: Properties of Waves and Color Vision (Wesley Lam)
nodes.description: Fill in the blanks, be careful for wrong answers!

typeData.textContent: Our group tapestry contributions from the group "Oranges". Here, we're going to situate some of the content we learned about in the Week 8 readings and lectures in the context of colour vision.

Colour blindness is a condition in which an individual does not perceive colour in the way other people due. First, to understand why some people are unable to see colour the same way others can, we need to review how colour vision works in the first place.

	Colour vision is a trait that many animals possess and it has a variety of uses, including object detection and object discrimination. In the human retina, there are rods and cones, which are receptors that work together in order for the brain to form an image. There are three different types of of cones, or photoreceptors, that detect colour: S cones, M cones, and L cones. The S cone detects  short wavelengths of  light, like the colour blue, M cones detect medium wavelengths, like the colour green, and L cones detect long wavelengths, like the colour red. These cone cells are located in the fovea, an area in the retina, and work best in bright conditions. We see more than just red, green and blue, which can be explained by the opponent colour theory, which is the theory that 3 mechanisms are responsible for the perception of colour, the opponency being between red and green, blue and yellow, and black and white. Then all visual visual information from the rods and cones are sent through the optic nerve in the back of the eye and is sent to the brain, which allows you to see shapes and colours.

	So why canâ€™t some people see colour? Well, often times it is not that people cannot see colour at all, which is possible, but sometimes it is that people find it difficult to distinguish between certain colours. There are three major types of colour blindness: red-green colour blindness, blue-yellow colour blindness, and complete colour blindness. Red-green colour blindness results in the individual having difficulty distinguishing red and green, blue-yellow colour blindness means the person has trouble distinguishing between red from yellow and blue from green, and complete colour blindness means the person cannot see colour at all. Most commonly, colour blindness is caused by some or all of the cones missing in the retina, which is typically a condition that people are born with. The type of colourblindness is caused by the type of cones that are missing. The effects of colour blindness can also be made worse in lower lighting because cones work best in bright conditions. 






National Eye Institute. (2019). Types of Color Blindness. Retrieved from: https://www.nei.nih.gov/learn-about-eye-health/eye-conditions-and-diseases/color-blindness/types-color-blindness

Turbert, D. (2019). What Are he Symptoms and Causes of Color Blindness?. Retrieved from: https://www.aao.org/eye-health/diseases/color-blindness-symptoms

nodes.title: Parts of the Eye and Colour Blindness (Lindsay Anta)

typeData.textContent:
CONES:
Our cones are the photoreceptor cells within our eyes which detect light and are very sensitive
to detail, and provide tremendous spatial resolution. Normally, humans have three color vision
cones and each of these cones is maximally sensitive to a slightly different wavelength of light.
Cone pigments generally have different levels of absorbance. These cones all work together to
allow us to perceive colour.
Cones are located in the back of the eye area known as the fovea, which is part of the retina
(light sensitive lining of eye).

TRICHROMATIC THEORY OF COLOUR VISION:
This colour vision theory is also known as the Young-Helmholtz theory of color vision because it
was initially proposed by Thomas Young and then later developed by Herman Von Helmholtz.
This is the earliest colour vision theory and is yet still very well known.
This theory was first proposed by Young in 1802 when he proposed that colour results from
the combined result of the three different receptor cones and that each receptor cone is sensitive
to a different range of wavelengths of light.
This was then later developed by Helmholtz in the mid 1800s where he expanded on Youngâ€™s
idea of colour vision. He proposed that the strength of the colour signal absorbed by the cones
determined how one would interpret color in oneâ€™s environment. He proposed that cones were
either short(~440nm), medium(~535nm), or long(~565nm) wavelength sensitive and each
corresponded to the colours blue, green, and red, respectively.
Helmholtz managed to determine this through an experiment and explained that normal
color vision requires the absorption of three wavelengths of light to create different
colours. Initially, he used color matching experiments where participants would alter the
amounts of three wavelengths of light to match a test colour. Then when participants would try
to match the test colour when given two wavelengths to alter, they were unable to do so. This
supported the trichromatic color theory, which would also then be known as the Young-
Helmholtz theory of color vision.
This theory explains how the outputs from the three cones combined for a single colourâ€™s
wavelength absorbed would result in a single colour that that cannot be confused for any other
single wavelength.

COLOUR VISION:
Color perception is incredibly important in our day to day lives. It can affect mood,
interpretations of the environment and can also stand for symbols within this world. It is
known through research that we are able to distinguish as many as 7 million different colours.
This perception of color is possible through the input of our photoreceptors cells also known as
cones, which are found densely packed within the fovea. There are multiple colour vision
theories such as the trichromatic theory of colour vision (which we discussed) and opponent
color theories. All these theories discuss our perception of colour vision.




References:

Barnes, S. (2020). Week 8, Lecture 5: Color Vision [Lecture Video PowerPoint]. Retrieved from Canvas

Cherry, Kendra. â€œVerywell mindâ€. The Trichromatic Theory of Color Vision, Kendra Cherry, 2020,
www.verywellmind.com/what-is-the-trichromatic-theory-of-color-vision-2795831. Accessed 22
July 2020
